docs.snippet: HOME VIDEO HAS always had a talent for revivals. Gather the films of a star or a renowned director, clear the rights, track down pieces of negative (inevitably scattered from Hollywood to Prague, or so it seems), box the special editions, alert th...
docs.lead_paragraph: HOME VIDEO HAS always had a talent for revivals. Gather the films of a star or a renowned director, clear the rights, track down pieces of negative (inevitably scattered from Hollywood to Prague, or so it seems), box the special editions, alert the cognoscenti to the second coming, or whatever coming this particular revival happens to be, and stand by for a warm response from fans and a public that increasingly likes to collect tapes. Nevertheless, one wonders what is in store for the revival of two works by John Cassavetes, the actor and fiercely independent director of a dozen films of total originality and sometimes annoying excess that challenged audiences for 25 years starting in the early 1960's.

headline.main: Once More Into the Fray For John Cassavetes

docs.snippet: Confronted by the failure of Italy's leading parties to agree on constitutional reforms, President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro signed a decree tonight dissolving both houses of Parliament, thus setting the stage for general elections on April 21.        ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Confronted by the failure of Italy's leading parties to agree on constitutional reforms, President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro signed a decree tonight dissolving both houses of Parliament, thus setting the stage for general elections on April 21. The decree brings to an end a monthlong crisis that began with the resignation of interim Prime Minister Lamberto Dini and ended with the collapse this week of a broad-based attempt to change Italy's flawed political system.

headline.main: Italy Cannot Form Cabinet And Plans Elections in April

docs.snippet: The German mark strengthened yesterday on the heels of Italian political problems, dragging down the dollar in the process.         The dollar fell against the mark as the German currency and the Swiss franc benefited from Italy's inability to for...
docs.lead_paragraph: The German mark strengthened yesterday on the heels of Italian political problems, dragging down the dollar in the process. The dollar fell against the mark as the German currency and the Swiss franc benefited from Italy's inability to form a new government. The mark, Europe's strongest economy, and the Swiss franc typically attract investment in times of political and economic uncertainty.

headline.main: Political Void in Italy Drives Up The Mark, Hurting the Dollar

docs.snippet: Hopes for a reform of Italy's political system collapsed today after the Prime Minister-designate, Antonio Maccanico, abandoned his two-week-old effort to form a new Government. His action indicates that parliamentary elections are  likely, perhap...
docs.lead_paragraph: Hopes for a reform of Italy's political system collapsed today after the Prime Minister-designate, Antonio Maccanico, abandoned his two-week-old effort to form a new Government. His action indicates that parliamentary elections are likely, perhaps as early as this spring. For the third time in a year, President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro must decide whether to appoint another candidate to try to form a Government, or to dissolve Parliament and call the elections he and many other political leaders hoped to avoid.

headline.main: Italians Fail to Form Cabinet, Setting Back Hopes for Reform

docs.snippet: The 68th annual Academy Award nominations were announced this morning and, like a good movie, the selection was a thorough surprise. "The Postman" ("Il Postino"), a small Italian film about a mailman whose eyes are opened to the world when he meet...
docs.lead_paragraph: The 68th annual Academy Award nominations were announced this morning and, like a good movie, the selection was a thorough surprise. "The Postman" ("Il Postino"), a small Italian film about a mailman whose eyes are opened to the world when he meets a famous poet, was nominated for best picture. So was another little foreign film, the Australian-made "Babe," a comic fable about a pig who yearns to be a sheepdog. Among the other surprises: Massimo Troisi, the star of "The Postman," who was virtually unknown in this country before the film was released and who died just after it was completed, was nominated for best actor. Tom Hanks, who won the best-actor award the last two years and was considered a shoo-in for a nomination this year, didn't get it, although "Apollo 13," the film in which he starred, received nine nominations, including one for best film.

headline.main: Oscar Nominations Are Just One Surprise After Another
